ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Governing equations derivation, application of complex math to real problems, more intuitive sense of differential equations
1. Basic concepts of geodynamics of the Earth. 2. Introduction to programming. 3. Mathematical knowledge to tackle geodynamical problems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: More context in the math heavy lectures would improve understanding! Strengths: clear notes, clear lectures, great use of visuals
I think the course covers a lot, which I think is really helpful

Strengths: 1. Good communication skills by professor. 2. General knowledge of the Earth's history was appreciated for students who may have not had a background in Earth sciences. Weaknesses/Improvements: 1. Assignment of relevant weekly readings would have helped. 2. Less relevance could have been given to strong form and weak form coding methods, which would have given more time to spent on problems in geodynamics.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if they're willing to put in a lot of effort.

Yes, definitely. Even though the course was difficult and the term paper and coding assignment took longer hours than expected, I learned a lot from the course. It is essential for any PhD student to understand the geodynamics of the Earth and this course ensures that.
